Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: The city newsletter includes a short survey about bus routes open through next week.
Story:
I stared at my screen, the Slack notifications piling up. The architects from three different teams were pinging me, all waiting for my input on the new feature specs. The launch date had just been moved up, and now everyone was blocked until I could make some decisions. My manager’s message was clear: “We need your answers today so the teams can move forward.” I felt the pressure mounting, knowing that any delay from me would ripple through the project.

Just then, my phone buzzed with the city newsletter. I remembered the survey about the new bus routes—something I cared about, since I relied on public transit every day. The survey closed next week, but I knew if I didn’t fill it out now, I’d probably forget. As a citizen, I wanted to give feedback, to help shape the city’s future. But as a developer, I was already behind, and the teams were waiting. My mind raced, torn between my responsibility to my job and my responsibility to my community, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
